That's great! Laravel and Tailwind are both excellent choices for building web applications. As for your basic programming experience, don't worry, you can still learn and build a Laravel web application with Tailwind. Here are the basic steps you can follow:

1. Install Laravel:
To start building a Laravel web application, you will need to install Laravel on your local machine. You can follow the installation guide provided on the official Laravel website: <https://laravel.com/docs/8.x/installation>
2. Set up your database:
Next, you will need to create a database for your application. Laravel supports various database systems, including MySQL, PostgreSQL, and SQLite. You can choose the database that you are most comfortable working with and set it up.
3. Create a new Laravel project:
After installing Laravel and setting up your database, you can create a new Laravel project by running the following command in your terminal:
```javascript
laravel new project-name
```
This will create a new Laravel project in a directory named "project-name."

1. Install Tailwind:
To use Tailwind in your Laravel project, you will need to install it using npm. You can run the following command in your terminal:
```
npm install tailwindcss
```
After installing Tailwind, you can configure it by creating a new file named "tailwind.config.js" in the root directory of your Laravel project.

1. Build your application:
Now that you have set up Laravel and Tailwind, you can start building your web application. You can create routes, controllers, models, views, and migrations using Laravel's built-in tools. You can also use Tailwind's pre-built CSS classes to style your application.
2. Deploy your application:
After building your application, you can deploy it to a web server to make it accessible to the public. There are various hosting options available, including shared hosting, VPS hosting, and cloud hosting.

These are the basic steps you can follow to build a Laravel web application with Tailwind. You can also refer to the official Laravel documentation and Tailwind documentation for more information and guidance.
